author: sky.cactus
content: <@!642887713246150666> Regarding your desire for a more clear decision making process for EIPs, I was thinking about it more and I think the root of the issue is that it is far easier to capture a clearly defined decision making process than it is to capture an ill-defined or dysfunctional decision making process.  The obvious downside to an ill-defined/dysfunctional decision making process is that legitimate participants in the process *also* struggle to get decisions made.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think a lot of the Ethereum community (especially on the dev side of things) has seen what happens when governance/decision making processes are captured and they are trying very hard to avoid that happening to Ethereum.  I think many would *rather* have a dysfunctional process than a captured process, which is why there is so much resistance to process formalization and having clear rules.

author: sky.cactus
content: This problem is much easier when there is a single benefactor in charge of things (like a CEO of a company), but that tends to not go well in the crypto-currency space because it paints a giant red target on the back of that person for state actors (regulatory agencies, etc.).  I *suspect* this is why those who may have the opportunity to seize power have historically refused to accept or delegate a leadership role beyond "influencer".

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the term Cat Herders is quite appropriate, because you are essentially trying to get a group of people who all naturally resist centralization to follow the same path (a centralizing process).  This is very much like trying to get cats, who instinctively do not cluster when moving, to cluster while moving.

<@!642887713246150666>  I don't think it's so much a matter of the community giving the  core devs power as them simply having the power.

For myself - as I say often - the community  doesn't pay me or indemnify me, so they have no right to tell me what to do.  It's not that I don't care about the  community, but that as a core dev I try to keep my decisions as technical as possible.

Other devs may of course disagree as to who the community is, how to know what they want, and how much weight to give that in their discussions.
